hypotheses: Intrinsic motivation is hypothesized to positively moderate the Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE), as highly motivated students might experience less pronounced effects.
Self-efficacy is expected to lessen BFLPE for students with high self-efficacy.
Elaboration and control strategies are predicted to positively moderate BFLPE.
Memorization is anticipated to negatively moderate BFLPE, potentially worsening its effects.
claim.hypotheses_location: Section on 'Motivational Constructs' in the summary of original_paper.pdf
claim.statement: Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE) suggests students in high-ability schools have lower academic self-concepts compared to those in mixed or low-ability environments.
claim.statement_location: Introduction and study overview in original_paper.pdf summary

data.notes: The study used a multilevel modeling approach due to the hierarchical structure of the PISA data.

method.description: The study used multilevel modeling to assess the BFLPE across different student characteristics, focusing on academic self-regulation and socioeconomic status using PISA 2003 data.
method.independent_variables: School-average ability, intrinsic/extrinsic motivation, self-efficacy, learning strategies

results.summary: The BFLPE was confirmed to have a negative impact on academic self-concept across various student characteristics, with minimal moderating roles by SES and motivation factors; memorization strategies exacerbated the BFLPE.
